intro.p: This article explains some steps towards a better performance.

section.title: Lazy load
section.p: Enable lazy load for relations as described on the User's guide: Enabling lazy load. Lazy loading can be defined at the class level as well, using [ActiveRecord(Lazy=true)].

Marking a class as lazy means that you all its persistent properties must be virtual (so NHibernate is able to intercept and load the property when it is required) and all accesses (even inside the class) to properties must be done using the properties (and not the fields).

note.p: Lazy loading is only possible when you are inside a scope!

section.p: Lazy loading is one of the more important tools in increasing the performance of an application, and like most performance related issues, it require testing in the context of the application to know what is the best solution for each scenario.

section.title: Overused Relations
section.p: If your code does intensive work on relations, consider replacing the operation by a HQL query. Databases are very optimized to handle process on a huge amount of data.

Using HQL, you can specify the data that you want to load, saving database roundtrips. For instnace, here is how we load a post with all its comments:
from Post p join fetch p.Comments where p.Id = 1
In almost all cases, it is better to ask the database for the data as expclictly as possible, rather than loading the data on demand. The HQL langauge is can bring a lot of power into your hands. Consult the NHibernate documentation on HQL for all the detials.
